headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Sen. Chuck Schumer (D-NY) Calls House GOP Agenda "Extreme"; Internet Sleuths Fill Social Media With Theories And Misinformation On Idaho Murders; Bill Richardson Speaks On His Negotiation Of U.S. Detainee In Russia. Aired 7:30-8a ET

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: On this.

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: No, it's OK.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Because I want to move on to a different subject. Do you want to go ahead?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I do want to ask you about the debt ceiling.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Go on.SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER (D-NY):  Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Because how sure are you?If we could pull up the sound from Jamie Dimon, the head of JPMorgan, this week. Here's what he said. Because you really explained it in Main Street terms. This is what actually -- we do have it or we don't? OK. But -- they'll let me know if we have it.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: He said it would be very bad, I presume.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Here -- just listen to him and then I want --

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: OK, go ahead -- yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: -- your take on the other side.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: JAMIE DIMON, CEO, JPMORGAN CHASE
utterances.sentences: I understand why Republicans might want to use it to get some stuff. And I'm not talking about the fight before the debt ceiling. I'm talking about on the day that America can't pay its debt. That has potentially disastrous outcomes.American debt doesn't cross-default but it's cumulative. If the T-bill defaults, and next week the T-bill defaults, and the next week T-bill defaults, pension plans have to sell. It is so potentially dangerous we shouldn't get anywhere near it. And after all the shenanigans of politics, we're going to have to fix this. I think it's very bad for the nation to be constantly looking at this type of thing. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: -- together, avoid brinksmanship and get this done. And not go right up to deadline.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I couldn't agree with you more. Tell me how you're going to do it. Because I remember --

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: We're going to --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: -- covering in real time the crisis of 2011, watching America's credit rating get downgraded. How are you going to do it so you don't --

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: I think --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: -- take America to the brink?

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: I think Republicans learned their lesson. They suffered. We won the election after that. And they will hopefully come and work with us and get this done in a bipartisan way. That's what we look to do. No brinksmanship.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So you spoke of the MAGA Republicans and you said going over a cliff. You used the "Thelma --

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- & Louise" --

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- analogy there.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So let's talk about George Santos. He is remaining defiant.Kevin McCarthy is refusing to say that he should step done. He goes, it's left to the people. It's left to the people. Listen, I don't want to play this sound bite because I want -- I just want to hear. Do you think that he should step down? Because he is saying that he is doing the work of the people. The people sent him there. But they sent him there on false pretenses.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: Look, he's told series of series, lie after lie after lie. Now there are several investigations going on and some of the charges are very, very serious.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: And so, I think we should let these investigations go forward and see what they produce.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: But you don't think Kevin McCarthy should stand up to say because --

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: I want to see what the investigators show. They may show -- they may show all kinds of things. These are serious charges, including misuse of campaign funds and stuff like that.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Paul Ryan said something really interesting to Jake Tapper yesterday about -- he said he -- I think I had too much power as speaker.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: (Laughing).

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You laugh. And he talked about ultimately, four people making all the decisions. So you're one of those four people.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: Yes, the majority leader.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Do you agree with him?

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, the way I do it is I have complete consultation with my caucus. When we came up with this bill -- the recent omnibus bill -- I let the committee chairs and the committee members on all the relevant committees have the input into the bill. So I don't think that they feel there were closed out. If, in the Republican side, they haven't done that, they should.We've had a lot of cooperation and overwhelming support for this omnibus where we got a lot done, again, on a bipartisan bill. We passed the ECA -- the Electoral College Reform Act and straightened that out. We passed the Fairness to Pregnant Workers so that women who were pregnant would be treated fairly in the workplace. We got increases in funding to feed kids during the summer when they weren't going to school. We got increases for law enforcement. We got increases for Ukraine and defense. We had a great bipartisan bill by consulting lots of people. And on my side, I do it all the time. I leave it -- I have very good members and great chairmen and I leave it up to them -- a lot of the decisions.

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: I have a question for you on the makeup of the Senate, but one last one on the debt ceiling. Can Biden raise it unilaterally?

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: Well, there's some discussion of that. I don't know -- I don't know how real it is.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Could it come to that?

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: Who knows? Who knows? Let's hope it doesn't -- no brinksmanship. For the last four times, despite all the early rhetoric, we came together when Republicans had power and when Democrats had power. I think that's what has to be done. You heard what Jamie Dimon said.Interest rates -- if we -- even if we get close -- excuse me -- and there's brinksmanship, it could raise your mortgage rate --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: -- you car rate, your credit card rate --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes, it would be devastating.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: -- your college debt rate. It's terrible.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Katie Porter announced she's running for Dianne Feinstein's seat. Dianne Feinstein has not said she is retiring.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: What's happening there?

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: She has not said she's retiring, so --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Is she retiring?

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: That'll be up to her. And --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Do you support Katie Porter?

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: No, I -- it's much too early. Dianne Feinstein hasn't even said she's stepping down.So I'm working right now with Sen. Feinstein to get aid to California with the terrible fires and flooding and all of that they've had.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Should Katie Porter have waited?

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: That's up to her. Dianne Feinstein hasn't stepped down yet.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: If -- have you spoken to her about it? In your conversations, do you discuss that with her -- the possibility of stepping down?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So as you are sitting there in the Senate and you're watching what's happening in the Congress --

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- with Kevin McCarthy --

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- or whatever, what is going through your head as --

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: What's going through -- LEMON

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: -- my head is as majority leader, I think I've led the most successful two years in the Senate, certainly since the Great Society and maybe since -- wait, wait. Yes, let me finish. Maybe since the Great -- maybe since --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: But I mean -- but what's to come for -- I mean, what's to come for the American people with all of this?

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: -- the Great Depression.I am hopeful and working towards a -- we may not have as much success as the last two years but the same kind of bipartisan things -- we helped -- we dealt with gun safety. We helped our veterans who had burn pits problems. We got the aid to Ukraine. We did so many -- so many -- we did the biggest change on climate to go -- to go against the carbon that goes into the atmosphere in history. We got a whole lot done. I'm not giving up the hope of getting that done now.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Do you think you can get --

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: I don't want to just have them investigate and have them pass these crazy bills that are led by a few extremists.And I do believe, again -- Don, let me just say this again. I do believe not in the next two weeks but in the next few months many of the mainstream Republicans -- when you talk to them privately they despise what these MAGA folks have done -- will come back. And that will give McCarthy some ability to come back and negotiate and get some real things done for the American people. Plain and simple.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Bills-Dolphins -- who's going to win Sunday?

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: Bills-Dolphins? Bills, please.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That was definitely -- why not Vikings-Giants? That's should be the question he's rooting for.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I know who questions this table.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh my God.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: I'm a Giant -- I've been a Giant fan since Chuckin' Charlie Conerly and Yelberton Abraham Tittle. I saved the Bills from moving out of Buffalo. I love them.The only dilemma I would face -- and don't ask me the answer -- is if it's Giants-Bills. Otherwise, I'm Giants NFC, Bills AFC.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Listen, thank you very much for that, and we hope that you'll come back as this whole -- COLLINS

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- as this whole classified document thing --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: We're not going to say classic.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- plays out.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: I'll come back with the Bills' Super Bowl pennant.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: No. But seriously --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I was going to say --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- we want you to come back when this mess --

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- is -- this classified documents thing plays out.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: You know, we talked about this --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: -- when I was last here right after the election, and I said I hoped the Republicans won't go extreme and work with us. We're keeping -- we're following through on that.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I was going to say classic politician taking two positions.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: No, no, no.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: The Bills-Giants.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: Well, they're great. It's not two positions. I root strongly --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: -- and strongly for the other.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Senator Schumer --

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: If it came to a Super Bowl, God knows.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Senator, thank you very much. We appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I didn't know it was -- thank you. SCHUMER

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Thanks so much.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: The man charged with first-degree murder in the stabbings of University of Idaho students in November back in court while police continue to seek any new information about Bryan Kohberger.Our national correspondent Gary Tuchman is in Moscow, Idaho this morning. Gary, good morning to you. What are you learning about Bryan Kohberger?

utterances.speaker: GARY TUCHMAN, CNN NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Don, good morning.Bryan Kohberger remains in this county jail here in Moscow, Idaho. We saw him in court yesterday for a status hearing. He waived his right to a speedy trial, so we won't see him in court again until his preliminary hearing at the end of June. All over the world, people are following this case closely, but for some, it's become rather all-consuming. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) TUCHMAN (voice-over):  Police and prosecutors are being required to stay quiet outside the courtroom about the University of Idaho murder case. But on the internet, there is no such prohibition --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE, TIKTOK
utterances.sentences: We have uncovered what we believe are some old writings of Bryan Kohberger.TUCHMAN (voice-over):  -- and most of it on TikTok, Facebook, and other places is speculation and hypothesizing.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE, TIKTOK
utterances.sentences: The evening following the murder, Kohberger's phone was pinged in Johnson, Idaho, which is three hours away from Moscow and conveniently next to a national forest.TUCHMAN (voice-over):  How prevalent is internet sleuthing? Consider this. This Facebook group, University of Idaho Murders-Case Discussion, has more than 225,000 followers. And this is just one of many groups discussing and hypothesizing about this case online. Prior to the arrest of Bryan Kohberger, a user who goes by Pappa Rodger was a prolific contributor on the site, with many creepy and insensitive posts and what turned out to be incorrect speculation, such as the white Elantra is a red herring. But he also declared, "Of the evidence released, the murder weapon has been consistent as a fixed-blade knife. This leads me to believe they found the sheath." The fact that he got the detail correct about the sheath despite getting so much else wrong is one of several reasons many on social media think Pappa Rodger was Kohberger. This person saying, "I really think Pappa Rodger was BK!" -- Kohberger's initials. And this person, "OK, this Pappa Rodger stuff is wild. How would anyone besides him know some of this? Very unsettling." There is no indication Facebook or the police believe Pappa Rodger, who is no longer in the group, is Kohberger. Then there is this video taken at an Idaho prayer vigil for the four murder victims prior to Kohberger's arrest, with many people hypothesizing online. ASHLEY GUILLARD, "ASHLEY SOLVES MYSTERIES," TIKTOK:  People think that the Idaho murderer attended his victims' vigil. TUCHMAN (voice-over):  This person commenting, "Bryan Kohberger. Spotted. Prayer vigil. Moscow, Idaho. And this person, "Sure looks like the psycho." But a T.V. crew from the newsmagazine "INSIDE EDITION" was at the vigil and has videotape of the man close up. It's definitely not Kohberger. We are not showing his face to protect his identity. And then, there is this.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE, TIKTOK
utterances.sentences: A lot of people have been asking who is Rebecca Scofield?TUCHMAN (voice-over):  A woman who calls herself "Ashley Solves Mysteries" has posted scores of videos on TIKTOK accusing a University of Idaho professor of participating in the killings. Never mind the police said the professor was never a suspect. The TikTocker, whose real name is Ashley Guillard, posted this video about two weeks before Kohberger's arrest.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: The preliminary hearing will begin on June 26. It could last several days. We expect prosecutors to reveal much more evidence.Last week, we learned that DNA was found on a knife sheath on a bed in the home where the four college students were murdered. Authorities believe that DNA is Kohberger's -- Don.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: All right. Gary Tuchman, thank you.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Welcome back to CNN THIS MORNING.An American who had been detained in Russia for nearly a year was released yesterday. Taylor Dudley, a Navy veteran, was in Poland last April attending a musical festival, was detained by Russian border patrol police after crossing into Kaliningrad, a Russian territory that lies between Poland and Lithuania. It's not clear why he crossed the border. But there is good news to share this morning that he is home. Joining us now, one of the people who negotiated his release, former New Mexico governor and former U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, Bill Richardson. Ambassador, thank you. Good morning. You literally -- like, two hours ago -- just got back, so thank you very much for joining us. BILL RICHARDSON, (D) FORMER GOVERNOR OF NEW MEXICO, FORMER U.S. AMBASSADOR TO THE UNITED NATIONS, HELPED NEGOTIATE RELEASE OF TAYLOR DUDLEY:  Well, thank you. This was a good news event. We brought back Taylor Dudley, the hostage. His mother went with us to the Russia-Poland border. This is not a high-profile case. It wasn't like the Griner case, which we were involved in, the Taylor (sic) Reed case. But the good news is that through local efforts with local Russian officials in Kaliningrad, which is far away from Moscow, a more grassroots effort resulted in the deportation and we were able to bring him home. The good news, I think, is that it shows that the Russians, on some of these humanitarian cases like the Trevor Reed case, like Griner, how with Taylor, and hopefully, with Whelan -- that they're ready to negotiate. They're ready to deal with these issues. I think that's the good news. And they deserve credit for turning Taylor over to us yesterday without much incident.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You were there on the ground -- on the border with his mother. How is he doing, physically? What is his health? How is his condition? How is he mentally processing this?

utterances.speaker: RICHARDSON
utterances.sentences: He's doing well. It was a very traumatic moment with Shelley, his mother, watching him cross -- almost like the "Bridge of Spies" movie process -- the walk.He's a very nice young man. He's a Navy veteran. He is somebody that has spent -- it's been six months and it was the family that contacted us to help because there was difficulty in the American embassy in Moscow, which is very far to visit him, to deal with him. And so, we were involved in getting the lawyers and doctors to help him through this legal process, which resulted in this deportation.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So I wonder what you think this tells you about Russia's willingness here, especially as it pertains to others being held there, including former Marine, Paul Whelan. The fact that Taylor Dudley was not released -- there was no prisoner swap here. Has something changed in Russia that indicates to you that it may be more likely than not that Paul Whelan is coming home?

utterances.speaker: RICHARDSON
utterances.sentences: Well, I believe that what we used -- the very grassroots support -- a legal process using attorneys from the region -- and we had worked on this case when we were working on Griner and Trevor Reed, mentioning at high levels in Moscow. But this was more rural grassroots attorneys that helped us -- Igor Bushamanov (PH), Andre Ballikan (PH) in Kaliningrad.I think this was -- this was a unique effort that resulted not in a prisoner exchange. It was just a --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: RICHARDSON
utterances.sentences: -- deportation.So I don't think the Russians necessarily are changing their mode, but their -- but their different cases require different approaches.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Well, I ask you --

utterances.speaker: RICHARDSON
utterances.sentences: And --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RICHARDSON
utterances.sentences: -- there are still little positive initiatives like these humanitarian cases -- Trevor Reed, Griner, now Taylor -- that are being resolved.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RICHARDSON
utterances.sentences: They're being resolved and they're reuniting with their parents and families.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And thank goodness for that. And thank you for bringing us the good news and the hope, and for all you do on all of these cases, Ambassador Bill Richardson.

utterances.speaker: RICHARDSON
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: RICHARDSON
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Well, that was then, this is now. Hear how Republicans and Democrats reacted to Biden's classified document case versus Trump's.
